<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_connection_value_n:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_set_connection_value_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                            const char *key,
                            size_t key_size,
                            const char *value,
                            size_t value_size)
{
  if ( (MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND != kind) &&
       ( ((key ? strlen (key) : 0) != key_size) ||
         ((value ? strlen (value) : 0) != value_size) ) )
    return MHD_NO; /* binary zero is allowed only in GET arguments */

  return MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_ (connection,
                                              kind,
                                              key,
                                              key_size,
                                              value,
                                              value_size);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if ( (MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND != kind) &&
       ( ((key ? strlen (key) : 0) != key_size) ||
         ((value ? strlen (value) : 0) != value_size) ) )
explanation: MISRA C Rule 21.17 concerns use of <string.h> functions that may access memory beyond object bounds. The only calls to such functions in this routine are the strlen calls shown above; these must be investigated because calling strlen on key or value that are not null-terminated can read past the objects. Other parts of the function do not invoke any <string.h> routines and therefore cannot directly cause the kind of out-of-bounds string accesses the rule targets: the comparison against MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND is a simple enum check, the ternary expressions only select between calling strlen or using 0 (the strlen calls themselves are already listed), and the final call to MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_ simply forwards arguments (its internals are outside this fragment and should be analyzed separately if needed). No other lines in this function call string.h functions or perform pointer-based string operations that would warrant investigation under Rule 21.17.
